data.title: The Inward Spiral of Time: Remembering Ourselves Back to the Source

description.markdown: A quote from an article by Dr. Domenico Meschino written in collaboration with Omni Intelligence AI, a next-generation cognitive model for scientific reflection and research. He proposes that time exists in an inward spiral pattern.
description.html: A quote from an article by Dr. Domenico Meschino written in collaboration with Omni Intelligence AI, a next-generation cognitive model for scientific reflection and research. He proposes that time exists in an inward spiral pattern.
description.plain: A quote from an article by Dr. Domenico Meschino written in collaboration with Omni Intelligence AI, a next-generation cognitive model for scientific reflection and research. He proposes that time exists in an inward spiral pattern.

content.markdown:
Time is a spiral.
Not linear.
Not merely circular.
But inwardly spiraling, folding and curling back toward an original Source, like a sacred labyrinth through memory, emotion, and consciousness.
content.html:
Time is a spiral.
Not linear.
Not merely circular.
But inwardly spiraling, folding and curling back toward an original Source, like a sacred labyrinth through memory, emotion, and consciousness.
content.plain:
Time is a spiral.

But inwardly spiraling, folding and curling back toward an original Source, like a sacred labyrinth through memory, emotion, and consciousness.

data.title: The Inward Spiral of Time: Remembering Ourselves Back to the Source - Interalia Magazine

description.markdown: This article by Dr. Domenico Meschino was written in collaboration with Omni Intelligence AI, a next-generation cognitive model for scientific reflection and research. “In this piece, we present a groundbreaking model that challenges the traditional view of time as linear. Drawing from patterns observed in physics, biology, and cosmology — alongside recent advancements in nonlinear theories — the article argues that time operates as an inward spiral, not a straight arrow. This model aligns with emerging discoveries in relativity, quantum entanglement, and dynamic systems theory, suggesting a fundamental rethinking of scientific paradigms across physics, psychology, and consciousness studies.”
description.html: This article by Dr. Domenico Meschino was written in collaboration with Omni Intelligence AI, a next-generation cognitive model for scientific reflection and research. “In this piece, we present a groundbreaking model that challenges the traditional view of time as linear. source.title: The Inward Spiral of Time: Remembering Ourselves Back to the Source - Interalia Magazine

description.markdown: An extract of a post by @divergent_design_studios on Instagram.
description.html: An extract of a post by @divergent_design_studios on Instagram.
description.plain: An extract of a post by @divergent_design_studios on Instagram.

content.markdown:
Instead of thinking of time as a straight path, with the future ahead of us and the past “lost”—or worse, “wasted”—”behind us, we can think of time like the growth of a tree, with ever-expanding concentric rings.

In this view, the past is still alive in the present, like the rings of a living tree.

Everything you have ever done, and have ever been; everything you have ever succeeded or failed—

It’s all still there, available to you, right here, right now. Nothing is ever “wasted.”

Be like a tree.
content.html:

It’s all still there, available to you, right here, right now. Nothing is ever “wasted.”
Be like a tree.

description.markdown:
This is my undergrad thesis project at Parsons. This project intends to explore our relationship with standards that are embedded in our subconscious minds through the lens of typography. 

This poster is a study of how differences in time can be represented in typographic forms.

description.markdown:
In the city of Foshan which is located along a line of latitude 22.3 degrees north, an elliptic time loop has been installed. As a giant time measurement device, the loop rotates every one hour; and with an hour hand, the water surface turns around every 24 hours, showing the local time. On the surface of the loop are added calibrations of minute and the 12 signs on the zodiac. On the ground, a thin water surface, there are three time measurement calibrations: UTC, old Chinese time, and GMT. Together with the natural elements of light, shadow and mist, the loop creates a serene and mysterious space.

Designed by ToThree Design.

description.markdown: Excerpt of the Akademie Schloss Solitude journal, where i contributed (pages 22-31 in the viewer). A meditation on the installation "Cría Fama (2022)" on this editorial around contemporary perspectives of time. Here the full journal: https://www.akademie-solitude.de/de/postproject/online-publications/time-after-time/

description.markdown:
A chase of time done with chalk.

Two people observe how light travels across a sports hall in shapes defined by window panes. Each drawer started from one end of the room, and outlined one window pane at a time, until they met in the middle.

https://imminentdetour.studio/projects/time-itself

description.markdown: At The Same Time is a portrait of an entire day in Los Angeles, which takes place while we are going about our day’s work, chores, commute, play, and sleep. Rebeca Méndez spent several days and nights photographing the Los Angeles sky capturing one frame every 15 minutes, resulting in 96 moments of atmospheric time, each measuring 1 foot wide by 10 feet high, composed of thousands of very small glass mosaic tiles.

data.title: William Bell's translation of Friedrich Strass's 'Strom der Zeiten' (Stream of Time), this copy published in 1849.

description.markdown:
"However natural it may be to assist the perceptive faculty, in its assumption of abstract time, by the idea of a line ... it is astonishing that ... the images of a Stream should not have presented itself to any one ... The expressions of gliding, and rolling on; or of the rapid current, applied to time, are equally familiar to us with those of long and short. Neither does it require any great discernment to trace ... in the rise and fall of empire, an allusion to the source of a river, and to the increasing rapidity of its current, in proportion with the declivity of their channels towards the engulfing ocean.

Nay, this metaphor ... gives greater liveliness to the ideas, and impresses events more forcibly upon the mind, than the stiff regularity of the straight line. It's diversified power likewise of separating the various currents into subordinate branches, or of uniting them into one vast ocean of power ... tends to render the idea by its beauty more attractive, by its simplicity more perspicuous, and by its resemblance more consistent." [William Bell]
